docs.lead_paragraph: International GERMAN PROGRAM FOR JOBLESS KEEPS RANKS DOWN, FOR NOW

docs.lead_paragraph: Patty Briguglio thinks President Obama may have a public relations problem selling his health care plan to small-business owners. And Ms. Briguglio, who was photographed exchanging a wagging finger with the president at his health care forum Wednesday in Raleigh, N.C., should know: she runs her own small business, MMI Associates, a public relations firm in Raleigh.

headline.main: To Challenges For Obama, Add Another

docs.lead_paragraph: Cross-posted from Floyd Norris's blog, Notions on High and Low Finance.
docs.abstract: The government is redoing the gross domestic product numbers. So it will look like we earned more in the past -- at least when there were disasters -- and like we spent less on health care.
docs.snippet: The government is redoing the gross domestic product numbers. So it will look like we earned more in the past -- at least when there were disasters -- and like we spent less on health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: It turns out The Agenda is not alone in thinking President Obama may have a public relations problem with small business. Patty Briguglio, who can be seen above, and on the front page of today's Times, exchanging a wagging finger with the president, agrees, and she should know: She runs a public relations firm, MMI Associates, in Raleigh, N.C. She's also a small-business owner.

headline.main: Obama Meets the Businesswoman: The Story Behind the Photo

docs.abstract: As the president made his exit from a town-hall event, one persistent small-business owner pressed him on the issue of taxes.
docs.snippet: As the president made his exit from a town-hall event, one persistent small-business owner pressed him on the issue of taxes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care talks will remain at the top of the agenda on Capitol Hill on Thursday, as lawmakers continue their push to broker some type of palatable plan before their August recess. There is not much time left, especially in the House, where representatives leave at the end of this week for five weeks.

headline.main: The Early Word: Looming Recess on Health Care

docs.abstract: The House gears up for a five-week break; while the Senate has one more week to wrangle over a committee draft of its health care legislation.
docs.snippet: The House gears up for a five-week break; while the Senate has one more week to wrangle over a committee draft of its health care legislation.

byline.original: By JANIE LORBER and KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, we wrote about a computer program to help older people drive more safely (DriveSharp). The article drew comments about whether aging drivers should be tested before having their licenses renewed. "Unleashing an aging Baby Boomer generation on the roadways will cause a genuine public health crisis in the years to come," one reader wrote.
docs.abstract: A greater number of older people are on the road, and they are driving more miles than before. And that number is expected to increase in the next 15 to 20 years, when one in four drivers will be 65 or older. But older drivers aren't the menace many believe.
